abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project in the
            Solomon Islands had a satisfactory outcome with unlikely
            sustainability, and a moderate institutional development
            impact.  While the Borrower's performance was
            satisfactory, the Bank's performance was
            unsatisfactory. The overall project design was considered
            weak as the project contained too many diffuse objectives.
            The Bank should have restructured and simplified the project
            design during its Mid Term Review.  In the area of community
            involvement and participation it was found that communities
            can be a catalyst for change and growth.  It is necessary to
            match project design to institutional capacity as a more
            focused project would have eased implementation and the
            achievement of development objectives.  Central programs vs.
            local initiatives to enhance educational quality, showed
            three needs: a) to strengthen the role of education
            authorities in tending to the specific needs of schools and
            addressing local educational challenges; b) distance
            learning or localized implementation of in-service teacher
            education; c) suitable and reliable distribution networks
            for textbooks and educational materials.  Behavioral change
            is a long-term process requiring sustained capacity building
            to accomplish lasting change in schooling practices.
            Greater integration with ministries could have reduced the
            work overload as well as fostered ownership and capacity
            building opportunities.  The relevance of sectoral
            monitoring was shown as, in its absence, critical issues
            were not immediately apparent, and, a greater focus on
            sector-wide monitoring and evaluation during the life of the
            project would have enabled greater prioritization and proactivity.
